Seem this PR lost a race with some changes to `WriteFiles` that cause NPEs in the display data because `filenamePolicy` ends up null, perhaps due to serialization. @jkff @reuvenlax does this sound familiar?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/12504537/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/12504537)

Coverage decreased (-0.09%) to 70.491% when pulling **12a285f5969ccec9ffed5c0d19840a733ef8062a on kennknowles:Pipeline-rehydrate** into **81c2e90f3a9d109121b686c25b642cc9f16ced43 on apache:master**.

Turns out they were just broken tests actually passing `null` for non-nullable values. And we don't aggressively check for null because the modern presumption is that nothing is nullable unless marked. We should probably be more defensive about user input, though.

OK, so now I have read the code more and I see that the pattern is that the user has to override `getSideInputs()`. This is an alternative we considered for `DoFn` in which has `ParDo.of(doFn)` would implicitly get wired up to have side inputs accordingly.

We did not choose it because we want to move towards a design where side inputs are a parameter of the `DoFn`, not baked in to its closure: The `DoFn` declares that it requires side inputs, and the construction of the graph with `ParDo.withSideInputs(...)` satisfies those requirements.

This makes the `DoFn` reusable in more contexts. We could always abuse a `DoFn` and do this anyhow, but this thoroughly violates the identity of a `PCollectionView` captured in the closure of the serialized `DoFn`.

Now take those three paragraphs and substitute `WriteFiles` and `FileBasedSink` and `.withOverriddenSideInputs`. So the situation is the same. With `DoFn` we are trapped by legacy but here we should start with the right design.

No need to apologize. Your PR was just fine. It is on us to either make it a core part of the API or document why it exists despite being unused. Since it was leftover for compatibility, one way to make it obvious would be with a test in `DataflowRunner`.

And [partial] rollbacks are painless - don't view it as indicating any fault. A large number of our tests do not run until postcommit (to avoid massive amounts of computation) so it is expected for such things to happen fairly often.
@iemejia How can we re-run jenkins job?
Retest this please

Thanks Thomas
Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-2663

@jkff I've begun to see your perspective.

Task 1 can be done with ParDo (as mentioned in the JIRA ticket, that's what we do currently).
Task 3 should be implemented separately from TextIO.
Task 2 can be done with Task 3 + ParDo.

The cons of building any further delimiting into TextIO itself outweigh any potential performance benefits.

Is there already an effort to build an IO that reads whole files as one?

R: @robertwb @kennknowles (either)

I don't think there is such an effort yet. I think I agree that it should be separate from TextIO because reading whole files could also mean reading binary files; and because the API for that requires some design (e.g. I'm not sure if we want to return a whole file as a String, as a byte array, or provide a user callback for parsing an InputStream into a stream of values of their desired type, like in MongoDbGridFSIO https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/io/mongodb/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/mongodb/MongoDbGridFSIO.java#L144). It's definitely outside the scope of this PR and if you would like to make this contribution, it would be very welcome but I would recommend to first discuss the proposed API on dev@beam.apache.org.

"Task 2 can be done with Task 3 + ParDo" - this I'm not sure, because of the above - we might be reading very large files whose content doesn't fit into memory. I think it could be reasonable to implement Task 2 as a feature of TextIO and that would be within the scope of this PR. "Reading multiline blocks of text delimited by a given line" seems like a reasonable extension of "reading lines of text" and compatible with other properties of TextIO. We could also extend TextIO.Write to emit output in this format too.
